head.title: Loving Arizona, Even When It Sizzles

hedline.hl1: Loving Arizona, Even When It Sizzles

block.p: Re ''The First Domed City,'' by Timothy Egan (column, June 16):
Re ''The First Domed City,'' by Timothy Egan (column, June 16):
As residents in the Valley of the Sun for 20 years, émigrés from the cold Eastern Seaboard, my husband and I have grown accustomed to the extreme high temperature during the summer months.

As one ages, the body experiences aches and pains, and for us, heat is a more comforting therapy than cold. Also, the dryness of the Arizona climate is far more tolerable than lower temperatures with heavy humidity.

I play a game as I open my car door with a pot holder after the vehicle has been sitting in the hot sun for a period of time. As I plunk down in the inferno of the car, I tell myself that I am at an expensive exclusive spa enjoying the healthful benefits of the sauna.

With magnificent views of the unique desert and mountains (Camelback up close), I luxuriate in the warmth with the hope that the sweat exiting my body is ridding me of poisonous toxins and extra calories.
How much better this is than shivering, scraping ice, bundling up from head to toe in my Eastern alma mater during the winter months.
